title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement adamhsparks@gmail.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/ code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https:// www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Beta-diversity Analysis with hagis
text: packages necessary analysis conducted. Import data used analysis. example data included {hagis} loading {hagis} become available R session. removes “MPS17_” isolates, read numeric instead character. next step removes “Rps” gene names, read numeric instead character. Set {hagis} arguments analysis. Please see vignette("hagis") details specify arguments functions package.
code: library("ape") library("vegan") library("dplyr") library("hagis") library("ggplot2") head(P_sojae_survey) # survey sample data ##    Isolate         Line         Rps Total HR (1) Lesion (2) ##      <int>       <char>      <char> <int>  <int>      <int> ## 1:       1     Williams susceptible    10      0          0 ## 2:       1       Harlon      Rps 1a    10      4          0 ## 3:       1 Harosoy 13xx      Rps 1b     8      0          0 ## 4:       1     L75-3735      Rps 1c    10     10          0 ## 5:       1    PI 103091      Rps 1d     9      2          0 ## 6:       1  Williams 82      Rps 1k    10      0          0 ##    Lesion to cotyledon (3) Dead (4) total.susc total.resis perc.susc perc.resis ##                      <int>    <int>      <int>       <int>     <int>      <int> ## 1:                       0       10         10           0       100          0 ## 2:                       0        6          6           4        60         40 ## 3:                       0        8          8           0       100          0 ## 4:                       0        0          0          10         0        100 ## 5:                       1        6          7           2        78         22 ## 6:                       0       10         10           0       100          0 head(sample_meta) # metatada about the sample collection locations ##   Sample   Locale ## 1      1 Michigan ## 2     10 Michigan ## 3     11 Michigan ## 4     12 Michigan ## 5     13 Michigan ## 6     14 Michigan P_sojae_survey$Isolate <-   gsub(pattern = "MPS17_",        replacement = "",        x = P_sojae_survey$Isolate) P_sojae_survey$Rps <-   gsub(pattern = "Rps ",        replacement = "",        x = P_sojae_survey$Rps) hagis_args <- list(   x = P_sojae_survey,   cutoff = 60,   control = "susceptible",   sample = "Isolate",   gene = "Rps",   perc_susc = "perc.susc" )

what: Convert the Dataset to a Binary Data Matrix
title: Beta-diversity Analysis with hagis
text: Using create_binary_matrix() transforms data correct format (binary data matrix) PCOA analysis. P_sojae_survey.matrix object contains RPS genes numbered rows columns numbered isolates. “1” indicates isolate caused disease RPS gene, “0” means .

title: Beta-diversity Analysis with hagis
text: following code transpose P_sojae_survey.matrix calculate Jaccard distances isolate. Jaccard distance calculations need used pathotype data presence/absence virulence. Lastly, PCOA performed identify variance explained principal coordinate. used later visualize identify distance pathotype groupings geographic location. example, Jaccard distances used presence/absence data. performing principal coordinates analysis, see scree plot says 70% variation Jaccard distances explained within first two dimensions (.e., axes). good. Usually good rule thumb second dimension roughly half variation explained first dimension don’t need look third n+1 dimensions.  Now can calculate percentage variation principal coordinate accounts . Another way calculate percent variation look Relative_eig column. Now can make data frame two principal coordinates account variation data. add metadata data frame pca.data.
code: P_sojae_survey.matrix.jaccard <-   vegdist(P_sojae_survey.matrix, "jaccard", na.rm = TRUE) princoor.pathotype <- pcoa(P_sojae_survey.matrix.jaccard)   barplot(princoor.pathotype$values$Relative_eig[1:10]) # Dimension (i.e., Axis 1 (PCOA1)) Axis1.percent <-   princoor.pathotype$values$Relative_eig[[1]] * 100  # Dimension (i.e., Axis 2 (PCOA2)) Axis2.percent <-   princoor.pathotype$values$Relative_eig[[2]] * 100  Axis1.percent ## [1] 50.39109 Axis2.percent ## [1] 21.79118 princoor.pathotype.data <-   data.frame(     Sample = as.integer(rownames(princoor.pathotype$vectors)),     X = princoor.pathotype$vectors[, 1],     Y = princoor.pathotype$vectors[, 2]   )

what: Add Metadata to your PCOA Data
title: Beta-diversity Analysis with hagis
text: need add information sample collection location data help identify different pathotype groupings based geographic location factors. use left_join() {dplyr} combine princoor.pathotype.data metadata ’ve already loaded, sample_meta contains geographic location (state name). Now plot PCA data using {ggplot2} color points based location, Locale, identify 95% confidence interval groups using stat_ellipse() function.
code: princoor.pathotype.data <-   left_join(princoor.pathotype.data, sample_meta, by = "Sample")  princoor.pathotype.data ##    Sample            X           Y   Locale ## 1       1  0.127655783  0.08704548 Michigan ## 2      10 -0.441075005  0.01573886 Michigan ## 3      11 -0.336826428  0.21804192 Michigan ## 4      12  0.217071376 -0.03795693 Michigan ## 5      13 -0.003862869 -0.14942952 Michigan ## 6      14 -0.108034781  0.18124849 Michigan ## 7      15  0.082862290  0.06501932 Michigan ## 8      16 -0.182559838  0.01610323 Michigan ## 9      17  0.043684771 -0.07086878 Michigan ## 10     18 -0.007048533  0.11629976 Michigan ## 11     19  0.224528803  0.06847162 Michigan ## 12      2  0.190565779  0.16984304 Michigan ## 13     20  0.081014587 -0.01986841 Michigan ## 14     21  0.156490576  0.15103874 Michigan ## 15      3  0.187665103  0.01477482 Michigan ## 16      4 -0.088772478 -0.14970662 Michigan ## 17      5  0.069295886 -0.06198926 Michigan ## 18      6 -0.088772478 -0.14970662 Michigan ## 19      7  0.102108599 -0.17330058 Michigan ## 20      8  0.102108599 -0.17330058 Michigan ## 21      9 -0.328099742 -0.11749798 Michigan ggplot(data = princoor.pathotype.data, aes(x = X, y = Y)) +   geom_point(aes(colour = Locale)) +   xlab(paste("PCOA1 - ", round(Axis1.percent, 2), "%", sep = "")) +   ylab(paste("PCOA2 - ", round(Axis2.percent, 2), "%", sep = "")) +   theme_bw() +   theme(     axis.title.x = element_text(face = "bold", size = 15),     axis.title.y = element_text(face = "bold", size = 15),     axis.text = element_text(face = "bold", size = 10),     legend.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 10),     legend.text = element_text(face = "bold", size = 10),     legend.key.size = unit(1, 'lines')   ) +   stat_ellipse(data = princoor.pathotype.data, aes(x = X, y = Y),                level = 0.95) +   ggtitle("Pathotype Jaccard Distances PCOA")

title: Beta-diversity Analysis with hagis
text: using two pathotype datasets comparisons, can use beta-diversity tests identify significant differences sampled pathotype compositions. code presented example downstream analysis can used comparing two populations’ pathotype composition. examples artificially split dataset two, analyses can shown. performing analyses likely two geographic locations compare already. Make sure can differentiate populations metadata file used previously (.e., column dataset specifies isolate came ; USA, Brazil, China, Australia, etc.).

previous_headings: Permutation Based Analysis of Variance (PERMANOVA) and Beta-dispersion Analyses
title: Beta-diversity Analysis with hagis
text: Beta-dispersion tests dispersion, variance, two groups significantly different . First, item named “groups” must made contains lists location number isolates location used analysis. check make sure lists “groups” adds number isolated used analysis. First, make list locations pathotype. Note using two locations need make list location length isolates used. Next, beta-dispersion calculated using Jaccard distance matrix made previously. ANOVA performed identify significance within dataset. Post-hoc tests can used identify significant interactions specific locations within dataset. can plotted visualize beta-dispersion different groups.  ANOVA identified significant differences groups dispersion (p = 0.3377355). means groups dispersion, variance, significantly different groups dispersion likely homogeneous groups. point, Tukey HSD test warranted, use example . , p-value 0.3377355 reported Tukey HSD tests reject hypothesis groups may different dispersion. can plot dispersion group using plot() function. expected, since identified significant differences, two groups dispersion overlap great deal distinct . shows pathotype dispersion groups homogeneous different instance. working data set groups significantly different dispersion expect see significant ANOVA p-value (p < 0.05) well significance using Tukey HSD test. Lastly, plotted dispersion form distinct, separate, groups can observed. Differences beta-dispersion may indicate separate pathotype groups investigated Permutation Based Analysis Variance (PERMANOVA) Analysis Similarity (ANOSIM) analysis. Groups similar dispersion may still significantly different regards centroids, tested using PERMANOVA.
code: groups <- factor(c(rep("Michigan_1", 11), rep("Michigan_2", 10)))  # this number shows how many isolates are in all "groups" lists combined length(groups) ## [1] 21 # this shows the number of isolates within your data set, these numbers should # match for downstream analyses to work!!  length(unique(P_sojae_survey$Isolate)) ## [1] 21 # calculates the beta-dispersion for each group, when comparing 2 or more pathotype.disp <-   betadisper(P_sojae_survey.matrix.jaccard, groups)  # tests if centroid distances are significantly different from each other pathotype.disp.anova <- anova(pathotype.disp)  pathotype.disp.anova ## Analysis of Variance Table ##  ## Response: Distances ##           Df   Sum Sq   Mean Sq F value Pr(>F) ## Groups     1 0.008375 0.0083752  0.9672 0.3377 ## Residuals 19 0.164523 0.0086591 # test significance between each group pathotype.disp.TukeyHSD <- TukeyHSD(pathotype.disp) pathotype.disp.TukeyHSD ##   Tukey multiple comparisons of means ##     95% family-wise confidence level ##  ## Fit: aov(formula = distances ~ group, data = df) ##  ## $group ##                              diff        lwr        upr     p adj ## Michigan_2-Michigan_1 -0.03998626 -0.1250853 0.04511275 0.3377355 # plot showing the dispersion for each group plot(pathotype.disp, hull = FALSE, ellipse = TRUE)

previous_headings: Permutation Based Analysis of Variance (PERMANOVA) and Beta-dispersion Analyses
title: Beta-diversity Analysis with hagis
text: PERMANOVA tests centroids, similar means, group significantly different . Likewise, R2R^2 statistic calculated, showing percentage variance explained groups. PERMANOVA identified significant differences groups centroids, means (p = 0.184). addition identifying significance group centroids, PERMANOVA also calculates much variance can explained specified groups (see R2R^2 column PERMANOVA output). case, R2R^2 0.0786944, 7.9% variance explained groups used analysis. Based PERMANOVA results can conclude two groups different likely similar pathotypes .
code: pathotype.adonis <- adonis2(P_sojae_survey.matrix.jaccard ~ groups)  pathotype.adonis ## Permutation test for adonis under reduced model ## Permutation: free ## Number of permutations: 999 ##  ## adonis2(formula = P_sojae_survey.matrix.jaccard ~ groups) ##          Df SumOfSqs      R2      F Pr(>F) ## Model     1  0.11358 0.07869 1.6229  0.184 ## Residual 19  1.32976 0.92131               ## Total    20  1.44335 1.00000

title: Beta-diversity Analysis with hagis
text: ANOSIM statistic (R) ranges -1 1. Positive numbers suggest similarity within groups groups. Values close zero indicate difference groups (.e., similarities groups). ANOSIM statistic (R) 0.0688182, similarities groups within groups. evidence groups different one another. Likewise significance >0.05 significant difference groups’ similarities.
code: pathotype.anosim <- anosim(P_sojae_survey.matrix.jaccard, groups)  pathotype.anosim ##  ## Call: ## anosim(x = P_sojae_survey.matrix.jaccard, grouping = groups)  ## Dissimilarity: jaccard  ##  ## ANOSIM statistic R: 0.06882  ##       Significance: 0.151  ##  ## Permutation: free ## Number of permutations: 999

title: hagis: Tools for Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity
text: following examples based dataset Michigan State University Phytophthora sojae surveys soybean phytophthora root rot pathotyping efforts. First ’ll want load data set, right now let’s use practice data set made {hagis} package, named P_sojae_survey. data set available R session automatically load {hagis} package. see gene column gene prepended “Rps”. can remove make graphs cleaner report genes tables manuscript. Note work string enter first value, pattern. second string, replacement, replacement value, third, x, look make changes. practice data set contains 21 isolates’, Isolate, virulence data set 14 differential soybean cultivars, Line. package uses percentage susceptible, inoculated, plants determine effective resistance genes, pathotype diversity frequency, well individual isolates pathotypes. help ensure proper data used calculations, user asked provide information instruct {hagis} data use.
code: library("hagis") head(P_sojae_survey) #>    Isolate         Line         Rps Total HR (1) Lesion (2) #>      <int>       <char>      <char> <int>  <int>      <int> #> 1:       1     Williams susceptible    10      0          0 #> 2:       1       Harlon      Rps 1a    10      4          0 #> 3:       1 Harosoy 13xx      Rps 1b     8      0          0 #> 4:       1     L75-3735      Rps 1c    10     10          0 #> 5:       1    PI 103091      Rps 1d     9      2          0 #> 6:       1  Williams 82      Rps 1k    10      0          0 #>    Lesion to cotyledon (3) Dead (4) total.susc total.resis perc.susc perc.resis #>                      <int>    <int>      <int>       <int>     <int>      <int> #> 1:                       0       10         10           0       100          0 #> 2:                       0        6          6           4        60         40 #> 3:                       0        8          8           0       100          0 #> 4:                       0 100          0 P_sojae_survey$Rps <-   gsub(     pattern = "Rps ",     replacement = "",     x = P_sojae_survey$Rps   ) head(P_sojae_survey) #>    Isolate         Line         Rps Total HR (1) Lesion (2) #>      <int>       <char>      <char> <int>  <int>      <int> #> 1:       1     Williams susceptible    10      0          0 #> 2:       1       Harlon          1a    10      4          0 #> 3:       1 Harosoy 13xx          1b     8      0          0 #> 4:       1     L75-3735          1c    10     10          0 #> 5:       1    PI 103091          1d     9      2          0 #> 6:       1  Williams 82          1k    10      0          0 #>    Lesion to cotyledon (3) Dead (4) total.susc total.resis perc.susc perc.resis #>                      <int>    <int>      <int>       <int> title: hagis: Tools for Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity
text: striven make {hagis} intuitive use possible. Part means used arguments three main functions, summarize_gene(), calculate_complexities() calculate_diversities(). functions take arguments: x data set name, e.g., P_sojae_survey example , allows function identify pulling columns (associated row values) use (.e. data collection Excel spreadsheet) cutoff value sets cutoff susceptible reactions. example, cutoff = 60 means genes 60% plants rated susceptible treated susceptible. can change whatever percentage require study. control specifies value used gene column denote susceptible control used study sample specifies column header column identifies isolates tested gene specifies column header column identifies genes tested perc_susc specifies column header column identifies percent susceptible plants gene Ordinarily use functions {hagis} R packages like : However, functions share arguments can create list() arguments share functions {hagis}. First, make list arguments summarize_gene(), calculate_diversities() calculate_complexities() use specify inputs based example data: Now list arguments, can now save time entering data function also avoid typos entering different cutoff values, etc. functions.
code: Rps.summary <- summarize_gene(   x = P_sojae_survey,   cutoff = 60,   control = "susceptible",   sample = "Isolate",   gene = "Rps",   perc_susc = "perc.susc" ) hagis_args <- list(   x = P_sojae_survey,   cutoff = 60,   control = "susceptible",   sample = "Isolate",   gene = "Rps",   perc_susc = "perc.susc" )

title: hagis: Tools for Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity
text: example tables graphics can produced using summarize_gene() function identify effective resistance genes tested sampled Phytophthora sojae population. summarize_gene() function allows produce detailed table showing number virulent isolates (N_virulent_isolates), well offering percentage isolates tested pathogenic gene (percent_pathogenic). Using pander library can make table much attractive RMarkdown.

title: hagis: Tools for Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity
text: {hagis} also provides functions quickly graph data using {ggplot2}. Two functions provided plot summary depending needs. need frequency, use autoplot(Rps.summary, type = "percentage"), desire distribution autoplot(Rps.summary, type = "count"). return graph, y-axis change; percent frequency n distribution.
code: autoplot(Rps.summary, type = "percentage") autoplot(Rps.summary, type = "count")

title: hagis: Tools for Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity
text: Pathotype frequency, distribution well statistics mean pathotype complexity can calculated using calculate_complexities() function. function return list() two data.table() objects, grouped_complexities individual_complexities. grouped_complexities returns list() data.table() object showing frequency distribution pathotype complexities sampled population. individual_complexities() returns list() data.table() object showing individual isolates pathotype complexity. isolates pathotype complexity refers number resistance genes able overcome cause disease , .e., pathotype complexity “7” mean isolate can cause disease 7 different resistance genes. , using pander can make tables much attractive RMarkdown. Since complexities list() object, can refer object directly name print follows. Using summary() return mean, standard error (se) standard deviation (sd) pathotypes complexities object.
code: complexities <- do.call(calculate_complexities, hagis_args)  complexities #>  #> Grouped Complexities #>     complexity frequency distribution #>         <fctr>     <int>        <int> #>  1:          1         0            0 #>  2:          2         0            0 #>  3:          3         0            0 #>  4:          4         0            0 #>  5:          5         1            1 #>  6:          6         2            2 #>  7:          7         2            2 #>  8:          8         7            7 #>  9:          9         0            0 #> 10:         10         5            5 #> 11:         11         3            3 #> 12:         12         0            0 #> 13:         13         1            1 #>  #>  #> Individual Complexities #>     sample N_samp #>     <char>  <num> #>  1:      1     10 #>  2:      2     10 #>  3:      3     10 #>  4:      4      8 #>  5:      5      8 #>  6:      6      8 #>  7:      7      8 #>  8:      8      8 #>  9:      9      6 #> 10:     10      5 #> 11:     11      6 #> 12:     12      8 #> 13:     13      7 #> 14:     14      8 #> 15:     15     11 #> 16:     16      7 #> 17:     17     10 #> 18:     18     10 #> 19:     19     11 #> 20:     20     11 #> 21:     21     13 #>     sample N_samp pander(complexities$grouped_complexities) pander(complexities$individual_complexities) pander(summary(complexities))

title: hagis: Tools for Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity
text: Two functions provided plot complexities depending needs. need frequency, use autoplot(complexties, type = "percentage"), desire distribution autoplot(complexities, type = "count"). return graph, y-axis change; percent frequency n distribution.
code: autoplot(complexities, type = "percentage") autoplot(complexities, type = "count")

what: Diversity Indices, Frequency of Unique Pathotypes and Individual Isolate Pathotypes
title: hagis: Tools for Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity
text: Diversity indices extremely useful trying identify differences two populations. , pathotype diversities calculated isolate population using calculate_diversities() function. Likewise, individual isolates’ pathotypes, number isolates used study, number pathotypes within study calculated. Five diversity indices calculated calling calculate_diversities(). Simple diversity index, show proportion unique pathotypes total samples. values gets closer 1, greater diversity pathoypes within population. Simple diversity calculated : D=NpNsD = \frac{Np}{Ns} NpNp number pathotypes NsNs number samples. Gleason diversity index, alternate version Simple diversity index, less sensitive sample size Simple index. D=(Np−1)log(Ns)D = \frac{ (Np - 1) }{ log(Ns)} NpNp number pathotypes NsNs number samples. Shannon diversity index typically 1.5 3.5, richness evenness population increase, Shannon index value. D=−∑=1RpilogpiD = -\sum_{= 1}^{R} p_i \log p_i pip_i proportional abundance species ii. Simpson diversity index values range 0 1, 1 represents high diversity 0 represents diversity. diversity calculated : D=∑=1Rpi2D = \sum_{= 1}^{R} p_i^2 Evenness ranges 0 1, Evenness value approaches 1, even distribution pathotype’s frequency within population. Evenness calculated : D=H′log(Np)D = \frac{H'}{log(Np)} H′H' Shannon diversity index NpNp number pathotypes. using pander reporting, nice table generated. Diversity indices n = 21 19 pathotypes.
code: diversity <- do.call(calculate_diversities, hagis_args) diversity #>  #> hagis Diversities #>  #> Number of Samples 21 #> Number of Pathotypes 19  #>  #> Indices #> Simple   0.9047619  #> Gleason  5.912257  #> Shannon  2.912494  #> Simpson  0.9433107  #> Evenness  0.9891509 pander(diversity)

title: hagis: Tools for Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity

title: hagis: Tools for Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity
text: Use {ggplot2}’s theme_minimal() theme.
code: Rps.plot <- Rps.plot +   theme_minimal()  Rps.plot

title: hagis: Tools for Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity
text: Set font bold-face serif family font.
code: Rps.plot <- Rps.plot +   theme(text = element_text(face = "bold", family = "serif"))  Rps.plot

title: hagis: Tools for Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity
text: Rps gene names long, flipping axis can make graph legible without rotating x-axis labels.
code: Rps.plot <- Rps.plot +   coord_flip()  Rps.plot

title: hagis: Tools for Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity
text: can use named, e.g., “red”, “yellow”, “blue”, colors R can use custom hexadecimal color codes. Illustrated using Michigan State University (MSU) Green, hex code #18453b, using theme_bw() serif font.
code: autoplot(Rps.summary, type = "percentage", color = "#18453b") +   theme_bw() +   theme(text = element_text(face = "bold", family = "serif"))

title: hagis: Tools for Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity
text: can sort x-axis graph produced using autoplot() ascending descending order using order parameter autoplot().
code: autoplot(   Rps.summary,   type = "percentage",   color = "#18453b",   order = "ascending" ) +   theme_bw() +   theme(text = element_text(face = "bold", family = "serif"))

title: Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity
text: goal {hagis} provide analysis tools plant pathogens gene--gene interactions R programming language original Habgood-Gilmour Spreadsheet, HaGiS, (Herrmann, Löwer Schachtel) provided. R package published MPMI resource announcement (McCoy et al. 2019). may wish refer paper information package.

title: Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity
text: {hagis} initially created Phytophthora sojae surveys Dr. Austin McCoy Dr. Zachary Noel Michigan State University US, disease managed primarily via deployment resistance genes (Rps genes, resistance P. sojae) commercial soybean cultivars application fungicide seed treatments. However, repeated use resistance genes can cause populations adapt time rendering resistance genes ineffective. determine current effectiveness resistance genes managing P. sojae, state-wide surveys (US) conducted determine pathotype (previously referred “race”) structure within sampled population P. sojae. However, package useful P. sojae work. built useful plant pathogen gene--gene interaction systems, e.g., wheat rusts, used animal science well, see Cain et al. 2022. goal package provide necessary analyses needed conducting pathotype surveys, including: distribution susceptibilities (effective non-effective resistance genes), distribution pathotype complexities statistics, pathotype frequency distribution, well diversity indices pathotypes efficient reproducible manner. New users encouraged visit documentation, https://openplantpathology.github.io/hagis/articles/hagis.html, detailed information use {hagis} along working examples using built-data set.

title: Analysis of Plant Pathogen Pathotype Complexities, Distributions and Diversity

title: Phytophthora sojae Survey Example Data — P_sojae_survey
text: object class data.table 294 observations 12 variables Isolate P. sojae isolate identifier Line Soybean cultivar Rps Rps gene identifier Total Total number plants inoculated HR (1) Number plants exhibit hypersensitive response inoculation Lesion (2) Number plants develop lesion inoculation site Lesion cotyledon (3) Number plants develop lesion, advances hypocotyl seedling infection Dead (4) Number dead plants observed inoculation total.susc total number susceptible plants (Lesion+Lesion cotyledon+Dead) total.resis total number resistant plants (equal HR value)

text: object hagis complexities object generated calculate_complexities(). Character. type vector values bar plot desired. Specify whether return graph frequency complexities percentage, "percentage", count, "count". Character. color named hexadecimal color value use bar color order sort x-axis bar chart ascending descending order frequency. Accepts ascending descending input values. Defaults complexity value. Character. ... passed chosen geom(s)

title: Plot hagis Complexities Objects — autoplot.hagis.complexities

title: Plot hagis Complexities Objects — autoplot.hagis.complexities
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # Using the built-in data set, `P_sojae_survey` data(P_sojae_survey)  # calculate susceptibilities with a 60 % cutoff value complexities <- calculate_complexities(   x = P_sojae_survey,   cutoff = 60,   control = "susceptible",   sample = "Isolate",   gene = "Rps",   perc_susc = "perc.susc" )  # Visualize the distribution (count or actual values) autoplot(complexities, type = "count")  # Visualize the frequency (percentages) autoplot(complexities, type = "percentage") }

title: Calculate Distribution of Complexities by Sample — calculate_complexities
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive()  # Using the built-in data set, `P_sojae_survey` data(P_sojae_survey)  P_sojae_survey  # calculate susceptibilities with a 60 % cutoff value complexities <- calculate_complexities(   x = P_sojae_survey,   cutoff = 60,   control = "susceptible",   sample = "Isolate",   gene = "Rps",   perc_susc = "perc.susc" ) complexities  summary(complexities) }

title: Calculate Diversities Indices — calculate_diversities
text: Calculate five pathogen diversity indices. Diversity indices include: Simple diversity index, show proportion unique pathotypes total samples. values gets closer 1, greater diversity pathoypes within population. Simple diversity calculated : $$ D = \frac{Np}{Ns} $$ \(Np\) number pathotypes \(Ns\) number samples. Gleason diversity index, alternate version Simple diversity index, less sensitive sample size Simple index. $$ D = \frac{ (Np - 1) }{ log(Ns)}$$ \(Np\) number pathotypes \(Ns\) number samples. Shannon diversity index typically 1.5 3.5, richness evenness population increase, Shannon index value. $$ D = -\sum_{= 1}^{R} p_i \log p_i $$ \(p_i\) proportional abundance species \(\). Simpson diversity index values range 0 1, 1 represents high diversity 0 represents diversity. diversity calculated : $$ D = \sum_{= 1}^{R} p_i^2 $$ Evenness ranges 0 1, Evenness value approaches 1, even distribution pathoype's frequency within population. Evenness calculated : $$ D = \frac{H'}{log(Np) }$$ \(H'\) Shannon diversity index \(Np\) number pathotypes.

title: Calculate Diversities Indices — calculate_diversities
code: calculate_diversities(x, cutoff, control, sample, gene, perc_susc)

title: Calculate Diversities Indices — calculate_diversities
text: x data.frame containing data. cutoff value percent susceptible cutoff. Numeric. control value used denote susceptible control gene column. Character. sample column providing unique identification sample tested. Character. gene column providing gene(s) tested. Character. perc_susc column providing percent susceptible reactions. Character.

title: Calculate Diversities Indices — calculate_diversities
text: hagis.diversities object. hagis.diversities object list containing: Number Samples Number Pathotypes Simple Diversity Index Gleason Diversity Index Shannon Diversity Index Simpson Diversity Index Evenness Diversity Index

title: Calculate Diversities Indices — calculate_diversities
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # Using the built-in data set, P_sojae_survey data(P_sojae_survey)  P_sojae_survey  # calculate susceptibilities with a 60 % cutoff value diversities <- calculate_diversities(   x = P_sojae_survey,   cutoff = 60,   control = "susceptible",   sample = "Isolate",   gene = "Rps",   perc_susc = "perc.susc" )  diversities }

text: Analysis plant pathogen pathotype survey data. Functions provided calculate distribution susceptibilities, distribution complexities statistics, pathotype frequency distribution, well diversity indices pathotypes. package meant direct replacement Herrmann, Löwer Schachtel's (1999) doi:10.1046/j.1365-3059.1999.00325.x  Habgood-Gilmour Spreadsheet, 'HaGiS', previously used pathotype analysis.

title: hagis 3.1.3
text: Sample names calculate_diversities() required numeric values. Previously, column converted numeric character values present, values became NA. allows greater flexibility analysing data sample names often descriptive just numerical value. Spelling corrections code comments Clean CITATION file README now complete information links MPMI paper

title: hagis 3.1.2

title: hagis 3.0.0
text: plot() now defunct. Use autoplot() plot {hagis} objects place plot(). avoid side-effect generating displaying plot every time plot() called, can troublesome using {ggplot2} themes since created two plots, original base theme new themed plot

title: hagis 3.0.0
text: Rename output column N_susc N_virulent_isolates Don’t round results summarize_gene() calculate_complexities() returning values user Implement fix suggested @zkamvar ensure user-input data changed data.frame tibble object data.table object R session Add ability sort graph x-axis ascending descending order based y-axis values rather gene complexity. Move example data set internal data provide documentation Provide documentation diversity indices calculated along mathematical notation possible display Calculate Shannon Simpson indices internally rather rely {vegan} reduce number Dependencies Replace term field column documentation Test coverage now 100 % Add funding agencies DESCRIPTION Authors@R field
